results.title: Le Schpountz = Heartbeat
results.brief_description:
A film-fan grocer is the victim of a practical joke played on him by a film crew touring his district of provence. He arrives at the studio in Paris on their false promises, but reveals himself as a successful comic. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide. Awards: International Moscow Film Festival (1959): Special Prize.

Credits: Director, Marcel Pagnol ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Willy ; music, Casimir Oberfeld.
Cast: Fernandel, Charpin, Odette Roger, Jean Castan, Orane Demazis, Leon Belieres, Maupi.

results.title: Quelque Part, Quelqu'un = Somewhere, Someone
results.brief_description:
Raphaelle, a young architect, is attempting to balance the demands of her work with the needs of the men around her. One of these men with needs is Vincent, her boyfriend, whom she tries to rescue from alcholic stupor in the hope he will finish his novel.

Credits: Director, Yannick Bellon ; writer, Yannick Bellon ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Loleh Bellon, Roland Dubillard, Christine Tsingos, Hugues Quester, Helene Dieudonne.

results.title: Solo
results.brief_description:
Vincent is a cello player and occasional drug dealer. On his way back to Paris he is informed that his brother Virgile is accused of criminal acts perpetrated on behalf of a group of revolutionary students. In a race against time, Vincent decides to get to his runaway brother before the police does.

Credits: Producer, Gilbert Marion ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Alain Moury, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; photography, Marcel Weiss ; music, Georges Moustaki ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Mocky, Sylvie Breal, Anne Deleuze, Denis Le Guillou, Henri Poirier, R. J. Chauffard.

results.title: Le Quatrieme Pouvoir
results.brief_description:
Yves Dorget, a newspaper reporter and Catherine Carre, a TV anchorwoman are both investigating the assassination of an Arab leader, who opposed the sale of two French nuclear reactors to his country. The pair become convinced that the French Secret Services are involved in the assassination, and just as they are getting a little too close to the truth, an order comes from ‘the castle’ to shut down the investigation.

Credits: Producer, Jean Kerchner ; director, Serge Leroy ; writers, Yannick Flot, Serge Leroy, Francoise Giroud ; photography, Andre Domage ; music, Alain Bashung.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Nicole Garcia, Jean-Claude Brialy, Roland Blanche, Bernard Freyd.

results.title: Une Fee Pas Comme les Autres
results.brief_description:
A young fairy entrusts her magic wand to a friend for safe keeping. Alas, a lover she once rebuffed decides to appropriate the precious wand and destroy the country protected by the fairy. Meanwhile a village preparations are afoot to receive, Barbara the famous singer, for an evening of unforgettable musical entertainment. Saturnin and a group of villagers must battle to retrieve the magic wand from evil hands and save their village. This children’s film is cast with live animals.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Bochart ; director, Jean Tourane ; writers, Louise de Villemorin, Jean Tourane, R. Lavigne ; photography, Maurice Fellous ; music, Richard Cornu.
Cast: Robert Lamoureux [narration].

results.title: Certaines Nouvelles = Certain News
results.brief_description:
Algeria, 1961. Laughter and music escape from an old sea-side house. Helene, Jean and Pierre try to remain oblivious to the reality surrounding them and their own insecurities. False illusion of peace and poisonned relations with friends are their lot while they attempt to spend one last summer as if nothing was happening. Award: Prix Jean Vigo 1979.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Meurisse ; director, Jacques Davila ; writers, Jacques Davila, Marie-France Bonin ; photography, Martial Thury.
Cast: Micheline Presle, Bernadette Lafont, Caroline Cellier, Frederic de Pasquale, Roger Hanin, Martine Sarcey, Gerard Lartigau.

results.title: Le Farceur = the Joker
results.creator_credit: Philippe De Broca and Roland Nonin
results.brief_description:
Edouard Berlon is a happy go lucky character who falls in love with the beautiful wife of a rich industrialist. Unfortunately she does not return his affections. The devastated Edouard reacts by playing sad songs on his bassoon while he waits for death. This eccentric behavior charms the woman into changing her mind and running off with him. His restored exuberance is again dampened when he discovers this beautiful woman is stone cold in bed.

Credits: Producer, Roland Nonin ; director, Philippe de Broca ; writers, Daniel Boulanger, Philippe de Broca ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Cassel, Anouk Aimee, Pierre Palau, Georges Wilson, Genevieve Cluny.

results.title: Clair de Terre = Earth Light
results.brief_description:
Pierre lives alone with his father in Le Marais district of Paris. He constantly thinks of Tunisia where his mother died when he was only five years old. He finally manages to travel accross to the country of his birth and meets Madame Lariviere, a former friend of the family.

Credits: Director, Guy Gilles ; writers, Guy Gilles ; photography, Guy Gilles, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Jean-Pierre Stora.
Cast: Edwige Feuillere, Annie Girardot, Patrick Jouanne, Roger Hanin, Micheline Presle, Elina Labourdette.

results.title: Le mariage de Figaro ou la folle journee = The marriage of Figaro
results.brief_description:
“This is detestable, it will never be played!” was the cry that rang out of the halls of French King Louis XVI when he read the script for a new play by Pierre-Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais (1732-1799), ‘La folle journee, ou Le mariage de Figaro’. The King felt that Figaro was impudent and disrespectful as a lower-class citizen because of the way he treats his superiors in the play. According to Louis XVI, the foundations of European social structure would be in jeopardy should this play be allowed to be produced - the truth of the matter was that private shows were going on all over Paris. The King finally acquiesced and the play was given publicly on April 27, 1784 - but not without a fair share of cuts and subtractions. Consequently, the play was a huge success, and was soon translated into German. On January 31st, 1785, Joseph II of Austria gave a memorandum prohibiting a German version from appearing in Vienna. It was not long after this edict was given that Mozart suggested to da Ponte that they use it as a subject for his new Italian opera. ‘Le mariage de Figaro’ (actually finished in 1778) is one of three in a set of plays written by Beaumarchais. Reference: http://www.artswire.org/~mrd/nozze/1784.beaumarchais.html

Credits: Producer, Pierre Guerin ; director, Jean Meyer ; photography, Henri Alekan ; music, W. A. Mozart ; technical adviser, Michel Deville.
Cast: Jean Meyer, Louis Seigner, Georges Chamarat, Jean Piat, Georges Descrieres.
